More Notes: A 1% increase in climate risk leads to approximately a 3% increase in the rate of long-term government bonds in developing countries, assumed to be measured in 2020.
Climate change led to an increase in the cost of public debt by more than 1.17% between 1996 and 2016. Value relative to 1996.

Climate change had a positive effect on the yield on sovereign bonds in Southeast Asian countries during 2002-2018. Specifying 0 as a placeholder since effect is positive but no value provided. Value relative to 2002.
Climate change could lead to significant economic losses, with costs accounting for between 2% and 21% of global economic output by the end of the century. Reporting lower end.

Sovereign CDS influenced by economic growth at the 90th quantile, inflation rate (except the 90th quantile), control of corruption (at all quantiles), political stability (the 75th quantile), or financial freedom (the 50th quantile).
Coefficient is statistically insignificant at the 10% level.
